It was working the first week of the current underway. And now the screen is frozen on the ad lockscreen. I've used others laptops, that has the kindle program as well, and held the button down and nothing. Which is becoming really upsetting. Its whole purpose of me buying it is now becoming non-existent.When it works, it works. But I might just have to find a e-reader with less finicky issues. Being underway isn't the best time for my kindle to act up. and being as we dont have wifi all the time, nor allowed to plug personal electronics into government computers. Its really becoming a hassle.

Thin and light, very handy physically.  Width is OK, an inch longer would have been nice.  Screen and usage buried in endless piles of unwanted Amazon marketing.  No practical way to distinguish what's actually on the device from all the garbage Amazon wants to sell you.  Navigation is awkward because of that, and too often gets itself locked into a dead-end, needing re-boot to start all over again.

Until now, I have used my larger older iPad (Gen2) as my permanent e-reader, but wanted something smaller, and lighter with a better battery life for traveling.  There is a little bit of a lag for starting up and some general navigation, but the page turning is very fast/smooth.  I tend to read at night in bed in the dark, so I prefer to have the black background with white font dimmed low.  Still trying to find the right mix of dimming that isn't too bright, but I can still read.  Because the screen is much smaller, I am turning the page more frequently, but it's not terrible.  The case itself is smooth, but not too slippery.  I am considering what I might be able to add/attach to make it a little more grippy without adding a lot of bulk/weight.  I wish it was a bit narrower, so it would be a little easier to hold with one hand, but I might consider adding some sort of strap to it like I have for my cellphone.  Overall, the price during Prime Days was right and it will be really nice for traveling or tossing in my bag when I might have time standing in line or sitting waiting for something to start.

reviewTitle: Solid E book, but has battery issues
reviewDescription: This is the second kindle I’ve bought.  It’s currently bricked and won’t turn on - says it needs to charge more but has been charging for a while.  Same thing happened to my first kindle.  You get about 1 year of it working then the battery goes.

reviewTitle: Most frustrating electronic device I have tried to use
reviewDescription: 1) It is hard to go from reading a book back to the library. Why not have a go-to library from sweep down from top?2) It is hard to create collections, find books not in collection, select and move multiple books to a collection, move books from one collection to another.  Collections look like an after thought.3) Send to Kindle gives me a "device is offline" with no further help. How to I get my Kindle online? Give me a little help guys....Also can't  send the book to a collection.4) Send to Kindle email does not work. It returns an email telling me this but not HOW to correct it. Also can't  send the book to a collection.I thought I was getting a mature product. I wasn't.5)

I've have four Kindles over the past decade and this is the first one that's had issues. Unfortunately I am past the return window. I should have returned it immediately when I noticed something was off. All the issues surround the kindle store and downloads. I have to restart the kindle each time I want to purchase a new book or I get an error message. It's like the kindle won't connect to WiFi without restarting. I LOVE Kindles, but mine is a dud.

The old Kindle Keyboard:1) Had Cellular Access2)  Displayed ONE LINE TEXT for the title - WHAT is with these huge book icons that limit what I can see on the Library page of collections titles to about 1/4 of what I could see on the screen ?3) Had a bigger reading screen4) Had a bigger body that was so easy to hold, and of course had an automatic keyboard5) Used buttons to turn pages that were gentler on the fingers than the low-response touchscreenAt least the Paperwhite still has airplane mode, but otherwise, I want a new Kindle 3, supported by Amazon!!!!  Even if it has to be without the 5G Cellular, or if that is extra.5) Was wonderfully glare-free
Almost too small for my liking. I would go for a larger size if I had the option.

I’m really unimpressed by the terrible response of the touchscreen. It is incredibly easy to get trapped on a page, suspiciously easy to get trapped on a page that insists that you rate the book and follow the author.
I’ve only had my kindle a little over 2 weeks and I hate it. It freezes constantly and battery last only a few days. I don’t know who to contact but it’s ridiculous
I like the reader BUT last charge was worth about an hour of reading. Don't like that it doesn't enable direct use of Libby. Why did it take so long to get...

Worst aspect the Kindle software is klunky and non intuitive.  Did not purchase a cover so hand holding the unit is difficult and not comfortable.  Oh the great battery life they talk about is gained with non usage of the product.  Keep reading a watch your battery drain on.Overall the whole premise of Kindle with the original promise of cheap reads never came to being.  Books are over priced for sure.  My conclusion is I will never venture down this rabbit hole again.  Give me a good old paper bound book and I’ll be a happy camper!

reviewTitle: One year old, probably dead, Kindle.
reviewDescription: The 2022 basic Kindle with 6 inch screen was my first Kindle purchase. In general, I've been pleased with it. I still prefer real paper books, but the Kindle is light, portable, easy to pack, and I can read items for less cost. I purchased it late November, 2023. Today it's not taking a charge. The amber light stays on for 3 seconds, then off. It's not the cables, not the charger blocks, and I've restarted the device. Probably a loose charging port. If so, this is unacceptable.

It EASILY gives me a message that moisture has been detected and prevents me from charging the device.  This message comes up even if I am reading it outside - no rain, no moisture.  Happens if my thumb happens to cover the charging port while I am reading. Happens at least once a day. Even since I have taught myself to hold the device differently.  Then when I get ready to charge, it will not take the plug in connection without giving me a stern message - the device has gone to no battery at all....  This has been a continuing problem for me since the day that I first opened turned it on.  This is the fourth Kindle that I have owned and I have NEVER experienced this problem before.

Really disappointed in this new Kindle 11, they really haven’t improved much since I bought my first one over 15 years ago. Same klugy sluggish software interface as before. And why can’t I change the time zone?, its stuck on Chicago time!

reviewTitle: In general a downgrade from previous model.
reviewDescription: Liked the light weight and size of device but too wide to hold comfortably in one hand. I ordered a case so I would have something to hold onto more easily but couldn't find the size information of this model easily and ended up ordering the wrong size case. Quality of print not good compared to previous older Kindle I owned. Also, screen jumped randomly forward in the book and not easy to tell where I was. Had to swipe back a page at a time until I finally recognized where I should be. No logical indicators at bottom of screen to tell where in the book you were. Hightlighting is a real downgrade. Also, font size not as adjustable as my older Kindle. All in all, not a good reading experience! If I had never had a Kindle before, I might have like this better. I wanted something I could read in bright light (which is not good on my phone), but couldn't get past all these things that seemed like downgrades from my old Kindle. If it hadn't died, I would still be using it. I returned the device and case and I went back to reading the Kindle app on my phone and found it eliminated all the things I didn't like about this model except the reading in bright light problem. Maybe when I can afford it, I'll try again with a better Paperwhite.

reviewTitle: Be aware! there is no color whatsoever. Black, white & gray -- reminds me of my first TV in 1949
reviewDescription: I know the trend in tech is smaller, lighter and greater resolution, but I didn't realize what impact the return to B&W would have on me. I felt let down, disappointed and a little bit angry that Amazon would expect me to give up so much of my Kindle reading pleasure just to have a more compact, lighter e-reader.Instantly, looking at my library, I felt like there was something wrong with my vision. I had been so used to seeing "my" books in full color. I plugged doggedly on, hoping that it would grow on me, but my revulsion at black on gray "highlighting" (really dimming) was almost visceral.I do light reading sometimes, but more often I read serious books, and really study them. My highlighting habits are a sort of dialog with myself, my education, and the author. The four colors of highlighting are useful for finding a passage again, or for a quick review when I've been away from a book for a while.I am grateful to Amazon for free returns, and used the opportunity to let "them" know how disappointed I was in the tradeoff from "the old Kindle" to this new form factor.Before you buy, ask yourself how important the color features (especially highlighting) are to you on your current Kindle. Better to wait until color e-ink is available, in my opinion.

When you hold down the touch screen to see further descriptions of things and you X out of it the background display will slightly show the previous screen closed or open. Very annoying and the only way to reset it is it you lock and unlock the device. For the price this device is not worth it.
Too small for me; just as easy to read on my phone or Ipad if I can want a larger screen. Returned.

This kindle is advertised as having a 6 week battery life… that’s a scam. Idk if they meant 6 weeks so long as you read 10 mins a day, bc it literally died on me at DAY 6…i bought this kindle right before I went on an 11 day vacation. I was super excited and didn’t see the need to bring the charger since it “lasts up to 6 weeks”. I couldn’t keep reading my book after day 6. Do better Amazon.

reviewTitle: More than one problem with this!
reviewDescription: It often skips a page--or more--when touching either back or forward. I won't waste my time contacting Amazon about this. Others have done so, received a replacement, and had the same problem.Also, the plastic housing is too narrow on the top and sides, making it difficult to keep from touching the screen and having the page go back or forward, plus getting some option other than the book I am reading.EDIT: I HATE THIS THING! It is non-responsive when touching a lot of the "buttons." And you must have WiFi connected even to DELETE a book.I have a much older Kindle (Generation 4, I think) with physical page-turn buttons on both sides. With this, I have to charge the battery every day, but I much prefer it to these "touch screen" things. And yeah, Amazon has a very expensive Kindle with page-turn buttons, but they are on the right side. Doesn't work for me because I read in bed lying on my left side...even if I would pay the high price.BTW, what's with all the "Generation" labels that I can never figure out? Can't they just use a model number?

reviewTitle: Kindle reader does not come with a charger
reviewDescription: I purchased this product for my daughter. It was delivered fast but there was no charger. Have you ever purchased a product that did not come with a charger?  Such crap…. Now I have to order a charger for this product. Thumbs down👎👎👎

It was a very good item for 6 months and then just went to a blank screen Warranty was good for only 3 months. Others that I have owned lasted for years. Does not make me happy to have such a failure in short term.

reviewTitle: Works well with Libby, ergonomical and well priced e-reader.
reviewDescription: I was considering purchasing a Kindle because I check out lots of books from Libby and read them on my iPhone and iPad. Both of those devices are heavy and hard to read from for long periods of time, and the screens tended to give me a headache after awhile, while paper text never did. I was pursuing a device that I could still read library ebooks with less headaches (literally) and sore arms and I’m happy to report Kindle serves this purpose well.The size is excellent. It’s a fair bit lighter than my iPhone 15 Pro Max, and sits a couple millimeters squatter but an inch and a half wider than it. This aspect ratio is pretty ideal for text, and you can switch to landscape orientation to make it even wider. I put a photo of it next to my iPad Air 5(? i think) for a size comparison there too. I found it to be a much more manageable size and weight for longer reading than both my iPhone and iPad, for which I’m pleased.I don’t own any ebooks at the time i’m writing this (but I might change that with the positive impressions I have of this device), so I was worried checking out Libby books would be difficult to use Kindle for, but once I linked my Amazon account, I was easily able to check books out and read them thru kindle seamlessly. Just note that if you try this, you won’t be able to read the book in Libby anymore on your smart devices; you’ll need to download the Kindle app to access them from anything other than your Kindle.I do think the Kindle is mostly worth the price you pay for it. I’m aware some of the Fire and other android tablets cost a fair bit less, but the e-ink screen on this thing is far higher resolution than my old Fire 7 tablet and the Kindle software is far less distracting for a more immersive reading experience. I do wish the screen was a bit more fluid and responsive, but that’s the tradeoff of an e-ink display rather than an actual defect with the device. I was actually quite impressed with the resolution, as pixelated text can annoy me quite a bit. None of that here! For a lot of people, the cheaper tablets with more functionality would be a better buy, but if you seek something to unplug a little bit while reading, this is an excellent option.

I’ve been wanting a kindle for a while now and I finally decided on this one. I picked this one mostly because it was the cheaper option and I was not disappointed. It’s super light weight and the screen is so easy on the eyes. The only thing I don’t like is that I have to charge is every night when I charge my phone. I kept reading reviews saying the battery life lasted so long (up to a month) and that has just not been the case for mine. I read probably around 6 or more hours throughout the day and I was hoping the battery life would last a few days. I’m not sure if there’s just something wrong with my kindle because everything else is perfect, it’s just the battery dies as fast as my phone does. I did see a review that said to put it in airplane mode and it makes the battery last a lot longer so I’m going to give that a try and see if it makes a difference. My absolute favorite part of the kindle though is kindle unlimited. It has so many great titles that I was seeing on TikTok that I had In my TBR.***update***I put my kindle in airplane mode to see if it made my battery last longer and it 100% did! I didn’t know it would make that much of a difference but my kindle is going on day 3 and still hasn’t hit 50%

I kept going back and forth between this one and the paperwhite… ultimately got the basic one and love it so much! I often get headaches while fading on my phone or my iPad but that’s not the case with this kindle. I can read for hours on this and still not develop a headache.Battery life is perfect! After I download a book, I turn it on airplane mode and the battery lasts weeks. I’ve had it for a month now and have only had to charge it when it arrived.Love the size! I bring this kindle EVERYWHERE with me!Saw mixed reviews on the touch screen quality but mine has been great. Lags a little but never bothers me. I turn it on dark mode at night and it’s perfect for night reading.Ultimately if you’re deciding between this or a paper white I would still recommend this to you. Just as great quality for a more affordable price.

I was surprised at how small it was but that kind of suits me for storage when traveling. I need a holder for it because there is nothing to cling on to over long periods. These things are pretty much known by most people and they a great alternative to people like me who don't collect books, although I have just one small complaint. Many pages have the word 'Highlighter' in feint text left by other readers which annoys me, it took me ages to learn how to remove it, (why leave that in as a default Amazon?). Other than that it pretty much does what it says on the can as they say.

I’m happy with this new Kindle.  It has the adjustable front light which works well for my night reading, and has just as much space as my more expensive Paperwhites. I don’t really miss the warm light setting and to be honest I wouldn’t have purchased my 2nd Paperwhite if this had been available. I love my other Kindles but wanted something smaller and lighter for night reading and this has worked very well for that. I don’t need to worry about a cover since it’s always in the same safe place.It has the same annoyances as my other kindles, too bright a flash on the page turns when on night reading, battery not lasting nearly as long as claimed (I keep them on airplane mode to save battery), intermittent freezing of the screen where you have to flip up from the bottom and forward the page using the smaller screen in the middle. This seems to free it up most of the time but sometimes I have to restart. Also, even after all this time to adjust, I still don’t like the new format after that big update and miss the simplicity of the old one. The Home section is useless to me and is cluttered and messy. The only thing I like is the ability to keep series together but even that doesn’t always work.I’ve posted a picture comparing my Kindle Paperwhite Signature 6.8”, Paperwhite 6.8”, and this new regular 6” with front light, all 11th gen. All are on the same settings for font, size and brightness. You can see how small and compact the new one is.

reviewTitle: Smaller than I thought, easy to use.  Took to long to get.
reviewDescription: I like the ease of use.  Just got it today and excited to use it as a daily reader and for Bible reading/study.  It is a bit smaller than I thought.  It will make for easy portability.  I also ordered a case and matte screen protector for it.The only issue I have is the length of time it took to receive this order.  We'll over a week and a half to receive this is crazy and it wasn't because it was on backorder.  If you don't need your Kindle right away it will get to you, eventually.  I was hoping to have mine by the time I went out of town which was last week.

reviewTitle: Won't let me download some of my Audible books so I can't listen to them
reviewDescription: I like the size and it is light to handle. But it won't download 3 or 4 Audible books so I can't listen to them. I will have to find another way to listen to them. The books that won't download are bought books not borrowed books so that's not the reason they won't download. They will download on my Amazon Fire HD 10 Tablet, but it is so heavy to carry around. So, I don't know what the problem is.

Wanted this cause it said it was just for reading which is all I wanted it for. Great for just sitting in bed or at the table or anywhere to read for as long as you want. I was using the app on my phone but would get annoyed with all the distractions such as text and calls. With this I do not have to worry about it. I did upgrade to the ad free just cause it was not that much more. Very light weight and fits in my purse great. Also love the Dark Mode on it. Only complaint I have on it is trying to switch books. It gives me an issue going from one book to another as I read several at a time cause what I read is based on my mood but other than that it has been working great.

reviewTitle: A good product with a couple of significant problems
reviewDescription: This is an extremely well made product. It's easy to use and read. I have only two significant complaints. It does not offer scrolling when you're reading, which is a better way to read on an electronic reading device. You can only "turn" the page. And it's hard to get a foreign dictionary to work well on it. I'm trying to read books in German to help with learning that language, and have installed a German-to-English dictionary. However, when I double-click on a word, instead of popping up a simple pane that provides the German word with its meaning or meanings in English, the Kindle offers three panes. One of the panes might occasionally offer what I need, but I must read through them. And the last pane, which is the hardest to access but is supposed to offer what I need, does not draw from the downloaded dictionary. It offers a translation from any language that has the word I clicked on in its lexicon. A surprising number of times, it's the wrong word in the wrong language. This is really a frustrating and counterproductive trait in the product.

reviewTitle: Great for Bible reading but only after some work and tweaks
reviewDescription: I got one for my grandma. Her eyesight isn't great but the font can be increased greatly. She reads it several times a day, much more than with the physical Bible which was extra large and heavy due to the larger print. Now she can read it in any position because of how lightweight and easy is to hold.Unfortunately Amazon doesn't sell a Kindle edition of the Russian Bible (Synodal translation) or a Russian New King James Version for that matter. I found a free Russian Synodal Bible online in epub format. After much trial and error I think I finally have a working solution. The best file format to convert it to is .kfx. I used Calibre x64 on Windows with Calibre plugins "EpubSplit" and "kfx output".According to other users and my own experience, Kindle readers have trouble with extremely large books (thousands of pages long), particularly the Bible. The Kindle would completely crash and reboot when opening the ebook or turning the page. I tried converting it to different formats that Kindle can read but it didn't help much. I ended up splitting the Bible into two books: Old Testament and New Testament. The New Testament is significantly shorter than the Old Testament but so far this split was sufficient to stop the Bible from crashing the Kindle. If the problem reappears I might further split the Bible into each respective book.This solution is good to keep in mind if you plan to read long books. The software and plugins I used were completely free.I recommend buying a Kindle case with a tight hand strap on the backside. It's allows you to securely and comfortably hold the Kindle with one hand. My grandma was delighted with her case.The backlight on the Kindle is difficult and inconvenient to operate, especially for older people. It requires too many swipes/touches to perform. I recently bought a Meebook M7 Android e-ink ereader and it rocks. It has physical page turn buttons each of which can be reprogrammed with 3 functions (press, double press and long-press). My backlight is toggled by long-pressing.Amazon should bring back physical buttons and more customization options. There's more competition in the e-reader market. Keep up or fall behind into irrelevance.

I happily used my Kindle on my Android for many years. Now that Amazon and Google pay don't play nice together, the time had come to get a Kindle device. I bought it and am very disappointed. The reading experience on my phone was much better and I find myself swearing at the Kindle regularly. Getting back to the home screens is difficult and navigation to buy new books is dreadfully slow and just plain bad. The touch sensitivity is poor. I'd go back to my Android device in a heartbeat if I could.

The first kindle i recieved, the screen was scratched. I was like no big deal it happens maybe it got dropped in transit, whatever. I return it and order a replacement. The second i recieved the back was scratched up. Both were delivered by different companies, so maybe it is happening before they ship or the packaging is not good for transit. But at this point i am settling for the scratched back cause i dont feel like doing another return process.ALL that aside, it is a nice reader kindle. No glare, like promised. Adjustable brightness, a dark mode for the night readers only downfall really is it is a little slow to respond to touch and scrolling (lagging behind a bit) not to big a deal while reading though. So 🤷‍♀️. Overall cant complain to much. It gets the job done but didnt really live up to expectations.

This is my 3rd Kindle. For the first time I am disappointed. I don't know if it's the material or that's it's so lightweight, but I can't move it around in one hand without it slipping around. A LOT.  It feels really fragile, probably a trade-off to being so lightweight. I'd rather have a bit more weight than these issues, which I didn't have with the previous versions that I didn't think were too heavy. My previous Kindle bought in 2016 had the power button on the back, top right corner. I could turn it on easily with one hand. This bottom button requires me to use two hands or brace it against my body. I don't like the thin sides. They are narrower than my thumbs, and I have small hands, so I can't comfortably grip it on the side. I also don't like the recessed screen. I miss my page turn buttons on the side, which allowed me to turn the page without moving my hand, and go to the previous page without setting it down or having to use two hands. I also don't like having to tap twice to get to the brightness screen, and then not be able to see the print when I'm changing it, to see how bright is necessary. The amount of brightness showing on a mostly blank settings page is different than with a full page of print. So I have to go back and forth to adjust it several times, holding it with two hands because if my thumb is off the side it will fall out of my hand. These things seem nitpicky, but when you're holding a baby, they matter! I don't want to be frustrated picking up my Kindle (slips out of my grip), holding it (side too small), turning it on (can't do one handed), and turning pages (no side buttons). Basically every aspect of this Kindle is annoying me. I'll use it, because it's amazingly convenient compared to an actual book, but as far as Kindles go, it's a huge disappointment. I'd give it a one star but I like the dark mode option, so I'll give it two.

The biggest reason for finally buying an e-reader was so I could read outdoors. The kindle does that great.  It's overpriced. It's so slow when highlighting a passage or switching between books. I've got two larger books that I can't use with Kindle device. The screen goes white or restarts itself. So I still use Kindle app on my phone for those books.  I've read the suggestion of restarting the device from scratch. Erase everything and try again. The issues were there as soon as I first setup the kindle, so I don't want to waste time trying that. I never had to do that with my $60 cell phone or $90 fire tablet. But it's required on the first day of a $120 kindle? Very outdated technology as well. Any books with photos are black&white. Kindle books are not substantial savings over a hard copy and considering the bright color photos in hard copies, kindle books have less value.  The entry model kindle is great for having multiple books in less space than hard copies take up. And entry model kindle is great for carrying books around through the day.  Overall, I feel stupid that I paid $120 for a device with $35 worth of technology.  If reading outdoors is not a big deal to someone, I would suggest a tablet with Kindle app for a lot less money, a lot faster system, and better graphics for books that have them.Update:  I finally hard reset my device. I waited a couple of months. Hoping an update would come along and make it more reader friendly. Waste of time. I loaded each book one at a time. I waited until the "busy" icon in corner was gone until I started to download the next book into my library.  It made no difference. The same books, purchased through Amazon, that would freeze the device still do it. Or they cause device to restart itself.  Hard reset did nothing. Setting the device up from the very beginning a second time did nothing.  Still slow response when trying to highlight a passage. And still freezing with two books I cannot use with Kindle reader and only use on phone app.

I have had this kindle for a little over a year, it has been great but suddenly it stopped charging. Of course the exchange period ended a couple months ago. I am not going to buy another one after spending money on this one for it to stop working correctly. I have a cover and screen saver and it has no damage and never been dropped or anything. I am definitely disappointed.

$100 for a flickery touch screen that only displays in black and white? In the year of our lord 2024? If anyone ever had a PDA or blackberry in 2005, this feels just like one of those. Although I'm pretty sure blackberrys had color displays.Aside from the strangely cheap, dated, monochrome device, reading is comfortable (even though the screen flickers with every page turn).

Super light and easy to set up, the pros. The big con is the limited options to adjust the font and font size. Due to visibility issues, I can only use an ereader. The screen is smaller than my soon-to -be discontinued Nook. There are only small/compact, medium and large font sizes. I need more than three.

This is the second time I’ve bought a kindle for a trip. Fool me once shame on you, fool me twice, shame on me. Of course I started a sample while I was at home and then tried to get the rest of it once I got me my hotel. I linked it to my iPhone at the initial set up so everything synced over on my home wifi. I connected my phone to hotel wifi and it was slow but worked. The kindle tried to connect to the hotel wifi, and I restarted it. It does not have the much needed capability to open a browser to add a name and room number. All it can do is take a password, but that’s now how hotel wifi connects. I had the same problem when I bought the child kindle for a 6 hour flight with my kid. Total nightmare, wouldn’t connect. Long flight with a bored kid, then still couldn’t get it to connect in the hotel. Not good for travel. I left a bad review for that one too and Amazon actually called me and tried to walk me through it, but of course I was in a car on my way to the airport and I asked them to call me back later and the never did

reviewTitle: more glitchy than my old kindle
reviewDescription: My old kindle was having trouble charging, regardless of which charger I paired it with, so I decided to buy a new kindle and went with this model. On a regular basis, it shuts down while I am reading and requires multiple restarts before I can continue reading. This started the week I got it and has continued on a regular basis since then. Not every read, but when it glitches, I can go through this sequence multiple times and wind up not getting to read during a window where I am trying to work in a little reading, like a short subway trip or between stages of active cooking at night, or a wind down at bedtime. Maybe I'm lucky but I had not had any -other- modern electronics as glitchy as this thing. Makes me wonder about the wisdom of continuing to build up a kindle-readable library and whether I should branch out to other devices. I am also doing a lot more reading of physical books again.

Not sure if I just got a defective unit, but nothing works.  It's easy to register the device, but impossible to deregister and delete wifi passwords.  When trying to read, it's incredibly clunky - the touchscreen is awful.  So slow you don't know if it's loading or didn't register the touch.  So you touch again and seconds later it crashes.  Incredibly user UNfriendly.  Bummed because I had a kindle in the past, but actually ran a lot smoother.If you get the one with ads, have fun being interrupted every other page with some ad for a book you don't want - but again, can't close out of the ad in a timely enough manner not to be disrupted in your reading.Sadly will be returning, was looking forward to a portable e-reader.  The design and weight is nice, very slick and size is perfect for on-the-go.  But when it's almost 100% non-functional, it's just a fancy paperweight.

reviewTitle: Finally after three tries I got a kindle that worked.
reviewDescription: I like all but the original set up - what a pain!  I ordered a paperwhite that was USED - how do I know?  The language on it was RUSSIAN!  So I returned it!  I ordered a second kindle and it came but I couldn't get it to work...thus I ordered another one and finally - got it to work.  THEN....the second kindle was being packaged to send back  and it started working!!  Arrrggghhh.  But I got a third kindle and I am now happy and love the new kindle!!  I bought the 16GB one and that is enough to handle 258 books in my kindle library.  Don't go for more GB - you don't need it.  what I DON"T LIKE is the lack of the button that says return to the front of the book like my 8 year old kindle has and the jump to the table of content feature....The new ones don't have it at least as far as I can find.  I will research to see if it is a "hidden" feature.  Other than that, go buy them, slip them in your travel bag, and get lots of great books.  This kindle is cheaper than buying books and carrying them around.  GO GET ONE!!  You're welcome!

reviewTitle: Works as well as any Kindle
reviewDescription: Light weight is good. It turned out to be slimmer than my previous model, so the elastic hand strap I’d been using with the old one doesn’t fit😕. In the upside, the smaller size and lighter weight mean my hand doesn’t get tired holding the thing, so the strap isn’t as important.

I purchased this kindle for a 92 year old friend who can’t hold heavy books to read. She does not have Sufi/ internet, but I was told to download the books and she can read without those items. The kindle keeps having a pop up stating to connect to internet. I took it to the library- made some changes. She read 2 books then it started back having the pop up. I have to drive over to her house when this happens- no matter how often. How do I get rid of the pop up for good?

I bought this kindle so I can lesson lugging around my iPad to read. Reading on my phone became annoying as well and I’d get distracted by notifications. So buying a kindle and making it be only for reading has helped me decompress better and zone out.

I very much dislike the fact  that most of the ads are for children’s books.  Also, I can't find the User's Guide for this Kindle, so navigating and finding different things on it is annoying.The back lights are very good, like the sizability of the font is good, and the general size is handy. I just dislike the preponderance of ads for children's books -- annoying.

I enjoy this Kindle since it is easier to carry all the time than my iPad. I do like to have something to read all the time in case I am out some where with extra time on my hands.My only concerns: it has not seemed to hold a charge as long as I was told. It isn’t a real problem since I a, used to charging other devices daily so I do this one whenever it is getting low. It also doesn’t seem to turn off easily. I do put in dark mode at night and press the button on the bottom, but it seems to pretty much stay on…even with the device lighting up during the night.Do,wish I could use a Book Funnel or Net Galley on this but I understand they want only Kindle used.

I love this compact sized kindle.  Reading is great.  However,  you can not of in the USB small Bluetooth adapter for headphones.  I use alienware and wanted to listen to audible.  I could not because it gives the error that it detects moisture.  I read this is common. This is very annoying.  My headphones are wireless and need the adapter.

I just wanted a basic Kindle to read my ebooks comfortably. It is all that. It's easy to adjust the brightness, fonts, and other settings and it's small and comfortable to hold and fits in my bag. The reason I took off a star is because it does not stay charged for "weeks." I read for about 2 hours every day, turning it off when I'm finished, and I've already had to charge it (after charging it fully when I received it) after ONE week. I put it on airplane mode to see if that helps. Still, if you read a lot like I do, don't expect it to hold a charge for much more than a week. Maybe they mean that if you don't use it at all and just let it sit there the charge will last up to 6 weeks, but that's kind of silly.

Edit updateI was contacted by Amazon customer service after the original review was posted. When I talked with them well all I can say is they were wonderful. They provided an exchange Kindle for me.In the process however of working through this with their representative. Andrew, who I thought was wonderful, I think we discovered that the problem is not in the Kindle but in the official Amazon case for it. The case is loaded with magnets. They apparently affect how the screen operates. I took the Kindle out of the case at Andrew's suggestion and the problem went away. I have now used the Kindle for several days with no problems whatsoever. I am switching to a different case, this one by Cobak, which at least initially doesn't seem to cause the problem. But I have only a few minutes experience with it so far. If I find anything out different I will add another edit.So, in summary, I think the Kindle itself is wonderful. I believe that the problem was caused by the case. I suppose that only time will tell. But my current recommendations is to avoid the official Amazon case for this Kindle.Original review:I have been using Kindles since the Kindle 2. And they were all wonderful. I wanted to come up to the latest, which I believe is Kendall 11. Of 2023. It's nice and some ways. It's a little bit lighter than the Kendall generation tens are. And it seems a lot faster.But it has a fatal flaw! Page turning is a disaster. If I tap to turn to the next page, it does so and after about a second or two it goes on to the next page after that. Sometimes two pages further. Nothing I do seems to help and the Kindle support people are essentially useless. Their suggestion was to restart it. And that does help for a variable number of page turns from one or two to 15 or 20. But it doesn't fix it. I am extremely disappointed. None of my prior candles have had this kind of a silly when I suspect his firmware problem.If I were you I would have avoid this Kindle.
Overall a great purchase, tho I got the one with the ads because it was on sale and thought it wouldn't be as annoying as it actually is, so if you're buying for sure get the one with no ads :)

I really love my Kindle, which I got recently after yearsssss of saying I'd never go to an eReader. I love having so many books at my fingertips, but it's definitely not perfect. The refreshing of pages is a bit lagged, which surprises me because they've had so many versions now you'd think they'd make it pretty high quality. Also, I don't like that I can't buy Kindle books on Amazon.com, you have to do it on the Kindle. I like to read the description etc of a few different books on different tabs before picking which one to buy next, so I have to do that on the computer and then switch to my Kindle when I've picked one. Seems strange to me?
I orded the latest kindle.  I just love it and recommend it to book readers

This is my 3rd Kindle since the first ones made.  They all have their little problems and takes time to figure it out.  This one needs a setting to bring up only unread book is, spend too much reading time deleting already read books.  Still the best one for the heavy reading I do, lot of all night sessions.

Overall, I love my kindle.THE BAD:The only thing that I really hate, is the store. The store is incredibly slow and glitchy. It takes forever to get to the book you want just because it freezes and glitches so much. Once you’ve found the book you want, downloading the book is very fast and easy - sort of makes up for the store being terrible. I usually just stay in the book once I have it downloaded, until I finish the book - I don’t exit out of the book each time I’m done reading - just because I don’t want to deal with the store and the library each time.THE GOOD:Once you are in the book and reading it - it is amazing. It is so convenient and I love that there are so many customization options (fonts, font sizes, 25 brightness levels, etc). My absolute favorite thing about the kindle is that it literally stays charged forever. I read for about 2 or 3 hours every day. I received my kindle at the beginning of July, charged it fully at that time - and I haven’t charged it since (today is the 29th of July) - it’s still on 58% charge. It has truly shocked me how long this thing stays charged. I love it.MIXED FEELINGS:It takes some time to get used to. When you “turn it off” - the screen is darker but it stays on with recommendations of other books. I was honestly quite confused when the screen didn’t go black or “turn off” how normal phones or iPads do. This took some time to get used to and I’m still not sure how I feel about it. But overall, I really enjoy reading on my kindle - I just wish they would make the store and library a bit faster and less glitchy.
It's a good kindle but I wish it was bigger.

I got this in July during Prime deals, and I am obsessed. I have read more than 30 books on it in the time I have owned it. I will say when searching for books, it is slow and the touch screen feedback isn't what you would anticipate. Compared to the Kindle Fires I have owned, I will be repurchasing this one if it ever gives out

In the past I’ve done all my ready through the Kindle app on an Apple devise.  I always wanted to try the Kindle to see if it’s easier on the eyes.  As far as reading, there’s nothing better.  Clear, light, incredibly battery life.  The only complaint I have is that the navigation on the app is much better.  The app is much more intuitive and easy to use.  There is no reason why the experience should not be the same.

Touch is slow and clunky. Buy this on sale, connect to your library card (don't have one, get one) and the Libby app. Plenty of free books. Love taking this on the road with me. Battery life is crazy long. Super lightweight. I bought the cheapest one on sale. Don't see a reason to get one more expensive.
Gift for my daughter and she loves it.

This is the second Kindle I have purchased.  I traded my keyboard Kindle (second edition) in when I received this one and I miss my old Kindle.  This one works great and is easy to read on, but I don't like moving through the settings or trying to move books around from category to category as it is harder with a touchscreen.  If the Kindle ever comes back with a keyboard I think I would go back instead of keeping the touchscreen.

So I am coming from a kindle 4 with page turn buttons…Yea it’s been a minute. I really thought I wanted the page turn and physical buttons cause I hate hate hate smudges on my screens when I’m reading. Well let me say that it’s a non issue with this kindle and this screen. I tried the paper white and not so much. Now the plastic on the Kindle basic is a fingerprint magnet but I can live with that. It is responsive, usb-c finally and has built in lights. Screen is much crisper than older kindles and reading at night with dark mode is awesome…I personally don’t miss warmth adjuster on the more expensive kindles at all but mileage may vary based on preferences. If reading is the most important thing you do this is the best option. It’s light, fits in pocket, battery is great, and no smudges on the screen. And if your trading in an old kindle you can get 20% off and a gift card as well. So this drops down to $80 depending on price point. So yea don’t spend more money on kindles that are not as good. Unless you like dropping your electronics in water or spilling items on your kindles…then get paper white but that would be the only reason I would ever make that choice…this is the perfect kindle at a perfect price.

I’ve always been a bit old-school when it comes to reading; there’s somthing about the heft of a book in your hands, the scent of the paper, and the sound of turning pages that’s just so comforting. But I have to say, the new Kindle Paperwhite has completly won me over.The screen is a real standout feature. It’s bigger than the older models, which means less page-turning and more continous reading. Plus, the backlight has this warm tone that’s really easy on the eyes—I’ve spent countless nights reading without any strain.It’s also super thin and light, which means I can throw it in my bag and not even notice it’s there. And since it’s waterproof, I don’t have to panic if I’m caught in the rain or if I want to read by the pool.But the battery life is what really blows me away. I charge it once, and it lasts for weeks. It’s perfect for someone like me who’s always forgeting to plug things in.And the books—oh, the books! There are so many to choose from, and it’s so easy to download them. I’ve been branching out into genres I never would have considered before, all because they’re right there at my fingertips.I have to admit, I’m pretty hooked on my Kindle Paperwhite. It’s just so convenient and user-friendly. I can change the font size, look up words as I read, and carry a whole library around with me. It’s not just a gadget; it’s a treasure trove of stories waiting to be discovered.Looking back, I can’t believe I waited so long to get one. It’s not just an e-reader; it’s been a gateway to rediscovering my passion for reading in this busy, digital age. If you’re on the fence about getting an e-reader, I can’t recommend the Kindle Paperwhite enough—it might just turn you into a bookworm, like it did for me.I’ve since bought two more, one for my mom and one for my dad.

reviewTitle: A device with a single purpose: reading
reviewDescription: Everyone has a smartphone these days, so at this point the Kindle is for one very particular audience: people who want to read a lot of books, and read them with a minimum of distractions.  With this version, Amazon has refined the Kindle to the point where it's just about ideal for this purpose.  I've owned several previous Kindles, including an early Paperwhite, and currently own a couple of iPads, an iPhone, and a MacBook.  For the purposes of long, immersive reading sessions, this Kindle is my best option.  The battery life is long enough so that even with constant reading you only have to recharge once or twice a week (you can extend that by turning off wireless).  The Kindle also has by far the best screen for immersive reading: it's sharp and clear, with many options for different lighting conditions ranging from bright sunlight (Kindles leave tablets in the dust as far as bright-sun reading is concerned) to pitch black (the dark mode format is ideal for this).  You can choose whether to read with a vertical orientation or a horizontal one -- and this option of a horizontal orientation allows you (among other things) to read poetry on a Kindle without imposing premature line breaks.  This Kindle is also extremely light and easy to hold for hours on end (my iPad mini is too heavy for that).  And as with all Kindles, you can adjust the type size and font so that reading is comfortable for you - I love paper books, I really do, but I need bigger type.In a way, though, what's best about this Kindle is what it doesn't have.  You can't read your email.  You can't go on social media.  Amazon's Kindle browser is perpetually "experimental" -- good!  I pick up the Kindle when I want to read books, not when I want to lose my afternoon down an internet rabbit hole.  That said, you do get just enough of the internet to assist in your reading.  From within any book you can look up unfamiliar names/places on Wikipedia, and there's a great built-in dictionary too.  (You can download dictionaries for any language you read, and set them as your default in settings).  But apart from those features, the internet might as well be on Mars.  Fine by me. If I want to look at videos of puppies or lose my temper about politics,  I have my phone (and several other machines, unfortunately).  When I look at my Kindle, I can feel my blood pressure go down.  More to the point, I can hide my phone under a cat and read books for hours and hours.That might not be your idea of an ideal afternoon.  If it is, and you know who you are, this Kindle is pretty inexpensive and much lighter and easier to carry than tablets or physical books.  It allows you to carry thousands of books around with you and then sit and read them without distractions.  It's limited in its other functions - and that's exactly what makes it ideal.As you can probably tell from the above review, I have the patience of a gnat when it comes to content I don't want to see, and for that reason I opted for the ad-free version.  This allows me to have the lock screen be the cover of the current book I'm reading, which is extremely endearing.  That said, the version with ads does not insert ads into your books; they're not obtrusive in that way.  So you can definitely save a few bucks by getting the version with ads - it won't mess with your reading experience.

I have been a kindle owner since 2008 and I have been running with the newest, biggest best. Most recent purchase was a kindle scribe - I love the size and functionality - but I rarely use it. instead I end reading on the iPhone kindle app. But I really missed the kindle - I wanted a kindle the size and ease of an iPhone. And so I ordered this and I am in love! Best ever.  The biggest drawback I keep reading is warm light - but the light seems very neutral to me - I have no issues with color of the LEDs (and I very much prefer warmth).  It is so small and easy to use and read and lightweight - I never had given any attention because I thought bigger and more expensive was better but I have discovered that this small and efficient kindle is my go-to. Love it. Thank you Amazon for making exactly what I needed yet again.

reviewTitle: Maybe my favorite Kindle yet! (And I’ve owned a bunch)
reviewDescription: I’ve been buying Kindles ever since the second model came out way back in 2009 or so. The Kindle is a marvelous invention that got me reading again and reading 3-4 times as much as I ever did with paper books. I have no romantic notions about paper and glue anymore.I’d go as far as saying the Kindle is arguably the most underrated invention of the early 21st century. But you’re here for the review, so…As for why I like THIS Kindle so much, well, I love the fact that all of the most important features have finally trickled down to the base model. I can afford to buy any Kindle I want and I usually buy one of the middle or high-end Kindles. This one was actually replacing an older Paperwhite, but I wanted to give the base model a try since it checked all the right boxes, aside from color temperature adjustment.The fact that all the best features are present on the base model now makes me feel better about Kindles and Amazon in general honestly. My first Kindle was $399, so I love the fact that this one is so affordable and within reach of a lot more people now.This Kindle also gets the fastest SoC (microprocessor) that the newest Kindles have. That means it’s as fast, or faster than any of the Kindle models.It’s finally got a generous amount of memory for anyone with anything but the biggest book collection. I’ll never fill it up I’m sure.It’s even got the higher dpi (resolution) Paperwhite screen now, so you’re no longer penalized with pixelated fonts or less contrast for buying the entry-level model and I LOVE that.One of my favorite features, though, is that it’s super small and light, which I really love. It’s the smallest, lightest, most pocketable Kindle there’s ever been. That’s a nice feature that makes you more likely to take it with you everywhere.The only things you’re really giving up versus a Paperwhite that I know of are the extra LEDs (I don’t miss them a bit, backlighting is more than enough) and the warmer color backlighting option (nice to have, but I can definitely live without it).This model also has a bit less battery life than the Paperwhite (maybe 15-20% less?) But it’s still a Kindle, which means it will last longer than any other device you own. I doubt the battery life will be a complaint from many.The final feature it’s missing is actually a PLUS to me. It’s the fact that the screen is recessed. I actually prefer that (I can’t be the only one). I like being able to tell by touch precisely where the screen begins. It makes it easier to avoid touching the screen accidentally and I just think it looks better to be honest.The only feature I WISH it had is PAGE TURN BUTTONS. I have no idea WHY Amazon has limited them to only the Oasis models. Other eInk book manufacturers like Kobo managed to find a way to include page turn buttons on nearly every model. Come on, Amazon.I had been planning on buying an Oasis for several years, specifically to get the page turn buttons. But I simply got tired of WAITING for Amazon to make an Oasis with USB-C charging already and update the hardware to match the newer models.I finally gave up on waiting for a USB-C Oasis after I read rave reviews of the new base model and Prime Day rolled around with a price drop on it.I’m super satisfied with it though. Lack of buttons aside, I think it’s my favorite Kindle yet due to the exceptional value, ultra-pocketable size and feature set.This model has everything I think most people really need and want in a Kindle at a very fair price (especially when you buy it during Prime Days like I did!).I also really appreciate the opportunity to buy a Kindle in a color other than black or white for a change. The Denim Blue is cool and different and that’s a feature you cannot get in ANY other Kindle model. Amazon should consider making a few more color choices here and there. I guarantee it would juice up sales.If they just added some sturdy page turn buttons to this, a physical switch to disable the touch screen, the “warm” backlighting option and gave it a bigger battery that’s designed to be easily replaced, it would be the PERFECT Kindle for me.That and I wish Amazon would give us greater control over our Home Screen. I just want a simple list of folders or my collections. I don’t want to see “suggestions” or any eye candy marketing fluff. Minor complaint though.All-in-all I think when you take price into consideration, this is the BEST KINDLE Amazon has ever made, hands down.

I’ve had my Kindle for over a year now. It took me years to make the decision to buy a Kindle because I was worried I’d hate it since I thought I would miss having a physical book in my hand, but I was SO wrong. I loved it immediately.No more were there lighting issues (shadows or not enough light from a lamp) while reading in bed or outside in the sun. No pages to have to hold back on either side of the current page you’re reading and having to balance in your hand.I was running out of space for my physical books. Now I have all my books with me in a small device which fits so easily in my purse or my pocket. I bought a cover to keep my Kindle from being damaged. I find that  eBay has the best deals on Kindle covers.I love all the features the Basic Kindle provides: search, font size, brightness of screen, long battery life, time on current page, toggle between page number, minutes left in chapter, hours left in book, sort by most recent book downloaded, title, author, publication date, ascending, descending for all books or collections (that you even have the ability to create your own collections), view by grid or list. Highlight favorite passages. Take notes. Plus so much more.Google and YouTube are your friends. Search for Kindle tips and tricks to learn all the things you can do on your Kindle Basic.I love Kindle Unlimited (KU). You get a lot of bang for your buck. It’s worth the money to get three months free for signing up for KU to make sure you like the subscription before committing to a subscription. I think you can get a monthly or yearly plan.I find the process of checking out a book directly from the Kindle to be a bit slow. So I do all my book borrowing and purchasing from my iPad or laptop.Read other reviews to see more tips.
When I first received my Kindle, I was afraid it would be to small.  I need larger print.  It's perfect.  Small,  lightweight,  and easy to read.  I highly recommend this item.

To be your first kindle is the best option buy one to try it and see how the experience, in two weeks I read a book, it takes me about 1 month to read a physical book, because I get lazy, but with the kindle is super easy to read, weighs nothing and is the size of the palm of my hand, I'm about to order another for my husband because it really is wonderful and encourages reading wonderfully.

If you’re considering this, and reading this review, you’re probably considering your first foray into Kindle reading. Good choice. A few things to note about this.The ads are not pop ups. I know some dead tree fans would have you believe, right in the middle of a tense scene, an ad will interrupt the page. That’s not how this works. What happens is, when you put the device in sleep mode, rather than say the cover or the portrait of a famous author, you see an ad. If you use the physical cover to turn on and off the device, you won’t see much if any of the ads.  And yes, you can dog ear a page.I have no idea why memes keep popping up to say you can’t. Actually, the things you can do with a print book that you can’t with a Kindle book are: Donate them to the library if the library starts taking books again, give used copies to a friend, sell used copies, have a bookmark accidentally fall out, and use them for, well, kindling. Kindle can do everything else. Things you can do on a Kindle and not a print book are: read in the dark, search for text, carry dozens of books in your pocket, create notes of virtually unlimited size (you run out of room in the margin of a print book), pick up a new book nearly anywhere, anytime, and instantly convert your entire library to large print.Most library systems can send any borrowed e-book directly to your Kindle. And your place and notes are stored in case you borrow the book again or buy a copy. You don’t get that with print.Amazon recently improved their send to Kindle features with a drag and drop web page that makes moving your own documents to the device extremely simple.This comes with a USB-C cable, but not a charger (aka wall wort) so if you don’t have one lying around (I think the expectation is most of us do) you will need to pick one up.16 gig might not sound like a lot, but most books fall under 2K.  I’ve seen public libraries (I’m looking at you, Florida) with fewer books than this can hold. Audible eats the memory a bit more, but I find this to be more than enough.You don’t get cellular connectivity with this, but that’s only with the premium Oasis line now. Scribe even missed out on that. I find it convenient, but I understand wifi is ubiquitous enough these days it’s not a big deal for most users. I have an annoying habit of finishing a book on the crosstown bus, then needing the next in the series. Yes, the cell phone tether works. No, that’s not as convenient as built-in cellular.It has fewer LEDs than most, but that’s not a big deal. Four lets you read in the dark. The scribe has 35. Guys, it’s an e-reader, not a disco, no one needs that many separate lights on that small a device. The absence of a warm light and auto adjusting lights are a bigger issue here. The warm light makes a big difference when you’re reading before bed.It doesn’t have the waterproofing, which I thought was a bigger deal when that first came out, but in all the time since I’ve yet to (knock wood) get a Kindle wet. It’s a nice to have, not a have to have.The size can throw people at first. The screen approximates two things – an index card turned portrait and a mass market paperback page. The occasional “ghosting” mirrors the see-through element of the cheaper mass market paperbacks, except on the device it refreshes quickly, and the ghosting goes away.There were some studies done that suggest memory is improved from reading from print rather than e-book. I want to point out a few issues and cite my own experience. First, all the studies I could find cite pop ups and other distractions as the primary issue. That is, the test is on a general-purpose tablet, not a single purpose e-reader. When they either do a study on an actual e-reader or compare with pop ups on the tablet vs someone coming over just as often and tossing brochures on their print book I’ll believe it. Unless all factors are equal, the study is inherently flawed. To my experience, my ability to absorb and either use the information (if it’s non-fiction) or retain it over time (if it’s fiction) is nearly identical in both, with the slight advantage of the e-book being able to search back in the text for prior information. It drives me nuts when a quote resurfaces in a print book, and I can’t find the prior mention again. Or when I need to find a code snippet in a shelf full of computer books rather than just search on device and have it in seconds.So, if you’re comfortable with the mass market paperback format, the size, the quality, then this is a huge step up. If you want to lay your hands on information quickly, then this is a huge step up.If you want portability, then this is a huge step up. I just had to help an elderly woman move into assisted living and the loss of space cost her nearly all of her much-loved library. I find it comforting that nearly all of mine fits in my purse. No more culling the library for space, then finding you need to buy a new copy. If you delete an e-book from your Kindle, you can download it again for free. I remember, in the dark days before the Kindle was invented, being stuck on a flight from Arizona to New York with nothing to read but the most misogynistic, worst written mystery novel I’d ever encountered. If I had a Kindle, I’d have had at least a dozen better choices at hand, not to mention rereads.The downside here is twofold. First, Dune and The Great Gatsby look the same size on the reader, so it’s hard to eyeball that one is a super-fast read and the other a meaty novel. It’s also a little too easy to build up a massive TBR pile, given it takes no physical space, the device memory is ample, and Amazon keeps offering free books to Prime members every month, sometimes more than one, and a crazy number of deeply discounted books Prime or not.If you are concerned about the environment, then this is a matter of economics of scale. On the last study I checked, the magic number was 20. At 20 books the manufacture and transport impact of the e-reader ties the impact of manufacturing and transporting print books. At 21 and beyond, the e-reader has almost no further impact as compared to the printing and transporting of physical books. E-readers have boasted substantial improvements in reducing their carbon footprint since that study, but I can find no more recent information. Even at 20, the worst number, it’s clear that e-readers are a pure win for the environment.It’s a great device. If you want to go with this one as the entry level, you won’t be disappointed.

reviewTitle: For the avid reader, there is no better option.
reviewDescription: At 158 grams this small Kindle is perfect for the reader who will regularly spend 2-8 hours per day reading.I own a bunch of e-ink readers. I have spent thousands of dollars on the e-reader technology over the years. When comparing all my dedicated reading devices it is the little Kindle that I prefer and it comes down to the sheer weight of the device.I found that when I read with even the slightly heavier devices such as the PaperWhite my knuckles cramp and my wrist is strained. Again, I am an avid reader, which means there are somedays where I can read almost uninterrupted for eight-hours in one sitting and with the 158g little Kindle I experience no wrist or knuckle strain. The device is really comfortable to hold for extended periods of reading.My only complaint is with the housing plastic. I have owned my little Kindle for maybe a year at this point and I take good care of it yet the plastic itself is of a such low quality, it is very easy to scratch and over time there is no way to avoid staining the (blue) plastic. Again, two or three times a week I wipe down the device. When I replace the device I will purchase a vinyl skin to wrap the entire device. That is the only way I can figure to keep the wear and tear from showing up on the little Kindle.Other than that, it is dollar for dollar the best device I have in the home.**I do have some major complaints with the Kindle store though. Their pricing for academic journals and texts is exorbitant and it is outright insulting in many examples. The Kindle Store has some essays on the store that have long been out of copyright protection and yet Amazon is sometimes charging well over $75USD for the respective text and again, that is insulting when I see it. The Kindle Store pricing model on scholarly work is one reason why I stopped buying Kindles for almost a decade.

This is super light weight and and easy to read. You can adjust the lighting to your comfort level. My only complaint is that it turns on way too easily when carrying in a bag.  The button should be a little harder to turn on.  It can be on for hours in a purse or briefcase without you knowing.
I had to upgrade my Kindle after 12 years. I don’t love the swipe function to turn the page, the lightest touch and it changes. I miss the side buttons on my old version.
As far as the Kindle itself it’s amazing it’s great. Probably the greatest thing since flush toilets. I just wish they included a wall plug and that’s why it gets 4 stars …..
This product was nice but I returned it due to the fact that it was too small. I felt like I was reading from my phone. Will get the next size up
Easy to carry around. It’s lightweight and very much convenient. My only dislike is it has a delay when turning on the device. But would recommend
I love how I can read on this screen in direct sunlight and change the font size - battery lasts for weeks !!!
The little button on the bottom of the screen is so small I can hardly see it, but i will get use to it.  I read on it every day.

reviewTitle: Good, except for need for frequent recharging

it's a little difficult to navigate for me. on the plus side light, print size and easy to read is excellent
I like the lit screen but my old one kept power longer

This is a great littler e-reader. The size is perfect for holding. The text and lighting was adjustable. Ultimately, though, I ended up returning it as I needed something that could run more than just Kindle Unlimited.
Received this as a Christmas gift. It is a little for my liking. It does fit into my handbag. You can adjust the font size. Still working with it hopefully it I can get it to where I need it
This is great for traveling, and when I read books laying down.It is lighter than most of my books and doesn't need a night light!
This was a good purchase but I bought used. And after just a few days the screen broke and I had to return it. I would definitely recommend to buy new to avoid this.

reviewTitle: So much easier on the eyes! I cant
reviewDescription: I love everything about it , accept you can't rotate the screen. It would be awesome if you could do that.
Good battery and charges quickly. Very compact and fits in a pocket easily. Extremely light!!

reviewDescription: Satisfied with performance. Hard for me to view selection of books in different areas, western, mystery, etc.

reviewTitle: Kindle Basic fine but not as fine as Kindle Paperwhite.
reviewDescription: Reviews praised the 16 GB memory and clarity of print on pages, fair enough and that's true. But the backlighting of the new, less expensive Kindle Basic isn't up to the standard of my years older, slightly more expensive Kindle Paperwhite. Wish I had known about that difference. Not Kindle's or Amazon's fault or problem but I cannot help but be a little disappointed.

i bought this device in the hope that the USB-C connector will last longer than the crap USB-A connectors on my three previous kindles - it's clear where they cheaped out on the previous versions. i probably won't know for a few years - check back.the kindle appears to have about 10 (presumably free) books on it when delivered; fear not, it is not a gift from amazon or the publishers, it's acually advertising, because they expired before i even got the device.
I love my Kindle. Just wish is was faster.

It does the job, I bought this product because I spend a lot of time in front of screens and when I tried to read on a normal tablet I just felt my eyes really tired and worst of all the blue light coming from it caused me difficulty to sleep. That changed with the amazon kindle, it's like reading on normal paper, my eyes doesn't get tired and I sleep on a normal way after reading.

I've been reading kindle unlimited on my phone for awhile but now this little thing is just so cute and easy to read off of! The screen is easy to use and is wonderful for any type of lighting including outside!
I had an old Kindle that wouldnt upload anymore. I really like the size of this new one and teh back lighting is perfect for reading in bed. Works how its supposed to and I would buy it again.

I've been reading almost everyday now for over two months, both manga and e-books, the image is crisp, you cam zoom on mangas and the embedded dictionary is really helpful. The battery lasts a lot (around two weeks on heavy usage) and charges fast.

I injured my hands a few yrs ago so they're not very strong anymore. Holding a phone for hours hurts. So im glad this kindle is light, its lighter than my phone. Ive been reading for hours and no pain in hands!

This kindle was replacing one that I had for 6 years. Never thought I needed a "upgrade", but boy am I glad I did. 11 gen is smaller but don't let that fool you. It moves so fast hardly no lag between.
As someone who is trying to decluttet my home, getting rid of all the physical hooks was huge! This is amazing and with the light I can read without disturbing the baby with a boon light.

I just bought my Kindle about a month ago. I love to read but hated having to go look through stores to find what I wanted, and REALLY HATED having so many books laying around the house after I read them. Now i can take my Kindle everywhere and read when I want with no hassle.

reviewTitle: WITH PATIENCE, YOU CAN GET A GREAT PRICE! I prefer it over the newest, largest Paperwhite.
reviewDescription: (Editing to reflect most recent purchase)I bought 2 more of these Kindles on Prime day, paying $65 each for them. I paid $80 for the first one of this model, which was also a sale price. (When I purchased the first one, I also purchased the newest version of the Paperwhite, which I find awkwardly designed to hold with one small hand. I named that one "Skippy" because of its tendency to jump more than one page at a time. It's a complaint found in many reviews of that model.)I have several older Kindles which have gotten a lot of use. Over time, it seems that they don't hold a charge as long as they did when they were new. I paid extra for the formerly-free 3G capability, which is no longer supported. (I think Amazon should give people credit if they paid the extra $20 or $30 for that feature.)This Kindle and the new Paperwhite use a USB-C charging cable, which I prefer because there's no "upside down, try again" issue. It sounds trivial, but it's a plus, imho. Now I won't have to use 2 different cables, depending on which Kindle I'm charging.I use several Kindles at a time: One in my purse (or 2 if I'm traveling where recharging is not an option). And 3 "scattered" around the house so that a Kindle is always within reach. I've also purchased others which I've given to my kids, loaded with books I think they would enjoy.I'm not sure what makes this model *not* a Paperwhite. It has the features I love/need/use the most (adjustable fonts, adjustable light, built-in dictionary, note-taking capability, etc.). The slight difference in weight is actually noticeable--and appreciated by my arthritic hands.I always purchase a magnetic cover that allows the device to wake up automatically when it is opened. (If you purchase on ebay, you'll find covers that are a lot cheaper than identical covers sold on Amazon.)My original review:It seems as if "they" constantly try to convince us that our devices (cell phones, tvs, computers, watches) are outdated technology. Too small, too large, too "flippy". This Kindle is probably as small as I'd want to go. If I wanted a smaller screen than this Kindle, I'd just use my phone.(The latest Paperwhite is noticeably larger than this device and previous Paperwhites. My preferred technique of holding it with one hand is more awkward with a larger device. It feels unbalanced, top-heavy. The cover is larger, too, of course, which adds more weight. I have arthritis in my hands, so it probably bothers me more than others. If I'm using a Kindle easel or holding it on my lap, it doesn't matter. But for one-handed Kindling, I like this little model. It's my new "travel Kindle".)I miss and resent the loss of free X-G for the Kindles. I paid extra for free 3G on my previous Kindles and it's useless now. It's not a huge hardship, but I have to remember to sync my devices before I leave the house. It can be a nuisance to find my place in my "purse Kindle" when I'm not home. (And Amazon loses out on those impulse purchases that I used to make when I finished a book and felt an urgent need to buy the sequel or something by the same author.)In conclusion, this is my new, preferred Kindle. My Kindle collection will now consiste of 3 of these, plus the larger Paperwhite I call "Skippy".

reviewTitle: Kindle is a Yes for me…
reviewDescription: I have to say I love reading and holding physical books and thought it would be difficult to transition. However, with recommendations I gave in and purchased a kindle and love it! I travel into the city for work and it is much easier to slip my Kindle into my small bag than it is a book. I do however still read physical books bc we also do need to support our library’s
Love this thing!!!! So nice to be able to have all my books available to me at anytime. Battery last forever! Beats trying to carry all my books.

reviewTitle: It still does everything I wanted.. just smaller and simpler.
reviewDescription: At first I was a bit disappointed as it seemed so flimsy with no outside buttons. After watching an excellent review of all three kindle and finding out how to use it I began to really like it.
Great size, easy to hold in the hand.  No extra apps so you can focus on reading and not interupted
This is so easy to use! The charge lasts forever. It's quick to update with the app on my phone. Fits comfortably in my hand and the dark view is great at night.

This is the third upgrade of the best e-reader in 12 years. Used nearly daily for thousands of books I like to upgrade as capabilities improve and it is time for an upgrade. Love the new size and improved capabilities for this latest iteration. Note that my retired paper whites are still fully functional. Best readers ever.
I was totally satisfied, and impressed with the piece I received. Good stuff. I am a satisfied customer. Good job.

Es un tremendo producto, me encantó, pasé de la 6ta generación a este y es abismante la diferencia. Es rápido y más ligero.Además me encantó la promo con lo que lo compré, era reacondicionado y venía en excelentes condiciones, como si yo fuera la única dueña.Lo compré a principios de febrero y aún me queda batería.

I love reading and used to read regularly, but got busy for four months. Picked up my kindle again assuming it was going to be dead because I never turned it off, and was pleasantly surprised to see that even with it being on, it still had 41% battery!Aside from the great battery life, the screen is easy to read, it is overall easy to use, and I highly recommend it for anyone that loves reading and wants something that is lightweight and easy to use.
The Kindlr I have at home does not light. Iquess the battery is not working! I ordered a new one and it has never arrived.
The best money I’ve spent ! It was getting so difficult for me to read, but with this i forget about anything else and spend hours reading. It came protected and in good conditions! 10/10 recommend 🥰

reviewTitle: after 6mos had tech problems, but customer service made right
reviewDescription: loved the ease of this kindle.  enjoyed the backlit feature.  However, after 6 months, the unit started experiencing technical problems and I found I was unable to use it.  This was totally unacceptable, since I purchased it new.  As a senior, I take care of my tech items, it's never been dropped, or abused in any way.  Frustrated, I left a poor review, and once I did, customer service reached out to me, and fixed the problem in under a minute.  I will certainly call them first next time I have an issue.  So far, the problem has not come back, so I am very pleased with the response time of Amazon and the kindle itself.  I am still a little concerned the kindle messed up to begin with, after only 6 months, but am reassured Amazon will respond promptly to my issue, should it arise again.

I received my kindle as a Christmas gift. So far I haven't done much with it. Can't attest to the battery life since I've only had it for a few hours. But I wanted to say that I LOVE how minimalistic it is. I spent ages searching for the perfect tablet and bemoaning how overdesigned products like Samsung's tablet line are, at least for my purposes, before realizing that I really just needed to get a dedicated e-reader (kindle)! So this product is exactly what I needed. One gripe is that one of my books (an e-textbook) isn't compatible. I wasn't expecting that. I can only read that book on my phone or computer on the kindle app. But that's not too surprising considering that this is the simplest kindle of the product line, and overall I just LOVE the kindle's simplicity. I'm a very distractible reader and this kindle makes it easier to focus!

I love this Kindle  which I bought as a replacement for two older Fire devices. the battery life is almost forever., the touch screen is very responsive.  the only negative IMHO, is it's size. After 2 Fire units it's just too small for me although I'm getting used to it. A plus is that it's easy to stick in a pocket and light enough so you don't notice.
